catch_line: REGULATION OF LIQUID PROPANE GAS TANKS.

1.text: L.P. (liquefied petroleum) gas shall mean and include any materials having a vapor pressure not exceeding that allowed for commercial propane composed predominantly of the following hydrocarbons, either by themselves or as mixtures: propane, propylene, butane (normal butane or isobutane) and butylene (including isomers).

2.text: L.P. tank shall mean container; any tank or container ranging from forty (40) pounds normal L.P. gas capacity to two thousand (2,000) gallons used for the storage or handling of L.P. gas.

3.text: Permit shall mean a fire prevention permit issued by the Fire Prevention Bureau.

4.text: N.F.P.A. 58 shall mean the current edition of Pamphlet No. 58 as written by the National Fire Protection Association.

5.text: Standard or Code shall mean the current edition of N.F.P.A. No. 58 “Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases”.

7.text: N.C. Administration Code, Title 2, Chapter 38, Section .0700, paragraph or rule .0701(1) as it pertains to installation and maintenance of L.P. gas containers from one (1) pound nominal L.P. gas capacity to two thousand (2,000) gallons L.P. gas capacity.

8.text:
National Fire Protection Association, Pamphlet No. 58, current edition of “Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases,” with the following exceptions: 
a.	When two (2) or more containers are manifold to a single service, each container shall be considered independent of the other and all ruler and regulations relating to a single container shall apply. 
b.	All cutoff valves and regulating equipment exposed to rain, sleet, or snow shall be protected against such elements either by design or by a hood. 
(Ord. No. 2011-873-TC-344, §1, TC-6-11, 5-3-11)

dublin_core.Title: REGULATION OF LIQUID PROPANE GAS TANKS.

plain_text:
CODE OF STATE

REGULATION OF LIQUID PROPANE GAS TANKS. (§ 5-2038)

(a) 

   (1) 	L.P. (liquefied petroleum) gas shall mean and include any materials
   having a vapor pressure not exceeding that allowed for commercial propane
   composed predominantly of the following hydrocarbons, either by themselves or
   as mixtures: propane, propylene, butane (normal butane or isobutane) and
   butylene (including isomers). 
   

   (2) 	L.P. tank shall mean container; any tank or container ranging from forty
   (40) pounds normal L.P. gas capacity to two thousand (2,000) gallons used for
   the storage or handling of L.P. gas. 
   

   (3) 	Permit shall mean a fire prevention permit issued by the Fire Prevention
   Bureau. 
   

   (4) 	N.F.P.A. 58 shall mean the current edition of Pamphlet No. 58 as written
   by the National Fire Protection Association. 
   

   (5) 	Standard or Code shall mean the current edition of N.F.P.A. No. 58
   “Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases”. 
   

(b) 

   (1) 	N.C. Administration Code, Title 2, Chapter 38, Section .0700, paragraph
   or rule .0701(1) as it pertains to installation and maintenance of L.P. gas
   containers from one (1) pound nominal L.P. gas capacity to two thousand
   (2,000) gallons L.P. gas capacity. 
   

   (2) 	National Fire Protection Association, Pamphlet No. 58, current edition of
   “Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases,” with the
   following exceptions: 
   a.	When two (2) or more containers are manifold to a single service, each
   container shall be considered independent of the other and all ruler and
   regulations relating to a single container shall apply. 
   b.	All cutoff valves and regulating equipment exposed to rain, sleet, or snow
   shall be protected against such elements either by design or by a hood. 
   (Ord. No. 2011-873-TC-344, §1, TC-6-11, 5-3-11)
